header.title: BITTER VENOMS: The Magical Worlds of William Burroughs

central_thesis: Phil Hine argues that William Burroughs' literary works function as a unique 'astral grimoire' or 'gay tantra,' providing a non-traditional, operative framework for exploring magical themes such as sex-demons, altered states for occult contact, time-travel through sexual shape-shifting, and various forms of sexual magick, often challenging conventional Western esoteric and moralistic views.

structure_content.summary: Phil Hine recounts his personal initiation into Burroughs' works, highlighting their influence on his understanding of 'nightmare culture,' sexuality, drugs, and magick, and positioning Burroughs as a guide to 'alien landscapes' and 'forbidden zones'.

This section analyzes Burroughs' objective approach to incubi and succubi, contrasting it with traditional occult warnings, religious condemnation, and psychological explanations. Hine notes Burroughs' view of these entities as 'familiars' that can be contacted, referencing *The Place of Dead Roads* and a distinct lack of anti-sexual bias.

The article explores how Burroughs posits vivid dreams, hypnogogic states, and lucid dreams as mediums for sex-demon contact, suggesting these encounters serve as 'training' for space travel. Burroughs' speculation on increased human-sex-demon interaction is highlighted, with reference to *A Report from the Bunker*.

Hine discusses Burroughs' themes of sexual divergence and biological adaptations for 'space travel,' leading to fictional worlds of entirely male societies and the evolution of the 'human artifact,' departing from concepts of androgyny.

This part details Burroughs' use of sex and sexual shape-shifting as a means to enter different time-space zones, including 'sex in the second state' (Astral Projection) and the use of 'cut-up sequences' to disrupt sexual conditioning and 'loosen' ego from linear time, drawing examples from *The Soft Machine* and *Cities of the Red Night*.

The author meticulously describes various sexual magick practices embedded in Burroughs' fiction, such as magical masturbation for thought-form projection, invocation of 'dark Gods' (e.g., Humwawa, Set) through sexual rites, and the 'orgasm-death gimmick' for ego/spirit transfer, often linked to hanging rituals and alchemy.

Hine concludes by reiterating Burroughs' work as an 'astral grimoire' and the only exegesis of a 'gay tantra,' asserting that Burroughs utilizes sex as a powerful 'escape vehicle' from societal control-programs and a means to explore male sexuality and magick untainted by conventional morality.

key_concepts.definition: Entities that visit humans sexually. Burroughs views them objectively as 'familiars' dependent on human hosts, capable of being contacted for 'favours,' contrasting with traditional warnings of vitality loss or religious damnation.

A magical formula described as a form of alchemy where the ego or spirit is transferred to another body at the moment of ejaculation, frequently linked with 'hanging rituals' in Burroughs' narratives.

key_concepts.term: Astral Projection ('Sex in the second state')
key_concepts.definition: A technique for non-physical sexual encounters and exploration, serving as 'training' for 'space travel' and a 'route into space' and imagination.

The operative use of sexual energy and acts (e.g., masturbation, intercourse) for magical purposes, including thought-form projection, invocation of deities, time-travel, and ego transfer, often deviating from conventional occult morality.

Burroughs' concept where sexual acts, conditioning disruption (cut-ups), or sexual shape-shifting allow protagonists to enter different time-space zones or 'loosen' from the addictive cyclicity of present time.

Phil Hine's term for Burroughs' work, characterizing it as a unique exploration of male sexuality and magick, distinct from conventional Tantra by its focus on gay experience and its freedom from traditional mysticism and morality.

practical_system.description: Burroughs' work, as interpreted by Hine, outlines a system where fiction serves as a 'grimoire' for radical magical operations, centered on the operative use of sex and altered states. The system encourages direct, non-moralistic engagement with 'forbidden zones' of experience. It involves leveraging sexual energy and consciousness to achieve specific magical outcomes, fundamentally treating the body and mind as instruments for trans-dimensional travel, communication, and transformation.
tools: The human body and its sexual functions (as the primary vehicle for magical operations).
Altered states of consciousness (dream-states, hypnogogic states, lucid dreams) as conduits for contact and travel.
Specific sexual acts (masturbation, intercourse) for channeling and projecting energy.
Sensory stimuli (incense, ointments, specific smells like 'stale sweat, rectal mucus and adolescent genitals') to facilitate invocation and atmosphere.
Mental techniques (cut-ups to scramble images, focused intent for thought-form projection, visualization during 'sex in the second state').
Potentially, 'sigils' (for initiating contact in dream-states) and 'psychic barriers' (though Burroughs' approach often eschews protective measures common in other traditions).
rituals: Contacting and interacting with sex-demons (incubi/succubi) for 'favours,' potentially involving psychic barriers or sigils before sleep.
Engaging in 'sexual shape-shifting' or disruptions of sexual conditioning (e.g., via cut-ups) to induce time-travel or access different time-space zones.
Performing 'Astral Projection' ('sex in the second state') for non-physical sexual encounters, understood as 'training' for space travel.
Employing 'magical masturbation' to project thought-forms or 'images of desire' at the moment of orgasm, shaping the 'astral light' to one's will.
Invoking 'dark Gods' (e.g., Humwawa, Set, Ix Tab) through specific sexual rites, often accompanied by designated olfactory stimuli and mental imagery.
Executing 'Orgasm-Death Gimmick' rituals, where the ego or spirit is transferred at ejaculation, sometimes in conjunction with 'hanging rituals' for alchemical transformation.

relevant_quotes.text: ...an incubus or succubus can be harmless, or it can be destructive. Like any sexual situation, the danger depends on how you handle it. All sex is potentially dangerous. Our sexual feelings make us vulnerable. How many people have been ruined by a sexual partner? Sex does provide a point of invasion and incubi and succubi simply make us more intensely aware of this.
If anyone could push a button and receive an incubus or succubus, I believe that most people would prefer a phantom partner than the all-too dreary real thing.
Xolotl was explaining to me that only one body is left in the switch they were going to hang me and when I shot my load and died I would pass into his body.
Carsons performs an act of magical masturbation to project a thought-form; he uses ecstacy to mould the astral light to his will, hurling the image of his desire at the moment of orgasm.

The orgasm-death gimmick is probably the best-known of Burroughs' sexual themes. It has been described as a form of alchemy, in which the ego is transferred to another body at the moment of ejaculation.

I have come to regard Burroughs' work as an 'astral griomoire'; or launch pad from which to explore male sexuality and magick. To my knowlegde, his work is the only exegesis of a gay tantra, untainted by the mysticism and morality found in other such explorers.

critical_analysis.relevance: This article is highly relevant for understanding William Burroughs' profound, yet often overlooked, contributions to operative magick. It uniquely positions his literary output as a practical source for esoteric experimentation, particularly within sexual and transgressive magical traditions. Hine successfully contextualizes Burroughs' themes within a broader occult framework, distinguishing his approach from conventional Western Esotericism and highlighting its precursor status to certain Chaos Magick tenets regarding subjective reality and results-oriented practice.
critical_analysis.target_audience: This analysis is primarily intended for advanced practitioners and scholars of Western Esotericism, Occultism, and Magick (especially Chaos Magick). It also appeals to literary critics and researchers specializing in William Burroughs' works, particularly those interested in the intersection of his fiction with counterculture, sexuality, and magical theory. The technical precision and focus on operative mechanics make it valuable for those seeking to understand or implement non-traditional magical systems.
